results.title: Rebel
results.creator_credit: Phillip Emanuel, Phillip Emanuel Productions and Michael Jenkins
results.brief_description: Rebel (Matt Dillon) has done enough. He wants out. The war has taken its toll; it’s wounded him, confused him and now it has sickened him. Rebel is deserting. He is on leave in Sydney, Australia. A guy called Tiger Kelly can arrange passage on a cargo ship back to America. All it takes is money. But that’s not a problem because Rebel wants to get home - whatever the price. Rebel is now a runaway, a fugitive. His fate is sealed. If he gets caught he gets shot. What Rebel needs is a place to hide out. Kathy (Debra Byrne) has that place.

results.title: Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm
results.creator_credit: Darryl F. Zanuck, Allan Dwan and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
Shirley Temple sings, dances and charms her way into everyone’s hearts in this acclaimed version of the Kate Douglas Wiggins story. When orphan Rebecca, (Shirley Temple), auditions for a radio show and doesn’t get the job, her stepfather, (William Demarest), takes her to live with Aunt Miranda, (Helen Westley), owner of Sunnybrook Farm. However, the show’s talent agent, (Randolph Scott), was prepared to hire Rebecca and begins to search frantically for the missing youngster - unaware the pint-sized radio star lives next door! This is a colourised version of the original black and white film.

results.title: Rebecca [DVD]
results.creator_credit: David O. Selznick, Selznick International Pictures and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: Joan Fontaine plays a modest and shy young woman, who meets, falls in love with, and eventually marries Maxim de Winter (played by Lawrence Olivier), a widower on vacation. When the new Mrs de Winter arrives at Maxim’s mansion, Manderley, she finds a house of hostile servants, most notably the housekeeper who works with sinister cunning to keep alive the influence of her late mistress, Rebecca. Hitchcock’s only Academy Award for Best Picture. Based on the Daphne du Maurier novel.

results.title: Rebecca
results.creator_credit: Hilary Heath, Carlton U K Television and Jim O'Brien
results.brief_description: Daphne du Maurier’s classic story of love, jealousy and secrets is revamped here with a British cast that includes Charles Dance, Faye Dunaway and Diana Rigg. Emilia Fox plays the modest and shy young woman, who meets, falls in love with, and eventually marries Maxim de Winter, a widower on vacation. When the new Mrs de Winter arrives at Maxim’s mansion, Manderley, she finds a house of hostile servants, most notably the housekeeper who works with sinister cunning to keep alive the influence of her late mistress, Rebecca.

results.title: Reassemblage: from the firelight to the screen
results.brief_description: This poetic yet intellectually rigorous documentary begins as an essay on Sengalese women but transforms to become an essay on the very subject of documentation, historical truth and Eurocentric “objectivity”. Trinh T. Minh-ha’s work has been pivotal in challenging cinematic assumptions about the representation of being “other”. Combining passionate theory with elegiac images “Reassemblage” is a critical history of the documentary and ethnography and one of the key works of Post-Colonial cinema.

results.title: Reasons for caring
results.creator_credit: Craig Johnson and National Fire Protection Association (U.S.)
results.brief_description: Following an explosion in an operating theatre, various people comment on the possibilities of fire in a hospital, the precautions to take and the potential for tragedy if a fire does occur. No matter why a fire starts, staff should know exactly what to do and where equipment is stored.

results.title: Rearing dairy calves
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Government Film Unit and Don Anderson
results.brief_description: Correct methods for rearing calves. Stresses individual feeding from buckets. To prevent digestive troubles and worm infestation, paddocks must be rotated. Calves must be drenched to prevent worms and if necessary vaccinated for black leg. Adequate clean and draught-proof shelter must be provided. Procedure for dehorning calves is also shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tasmanian Government Film Unit and Don Anderson

results.title: Rear window [DVD]
results.brief_description: A freelance travelling news photographer with a broken leg is confined in his Greenwich Village apartment during a New York heatwave. A voyeuristic impulse leads him from curiosity to suspicion of murder as he observes his neighbours in the apartments opposite. His morbid curiosity is marked by a switch from binoculars to a telephoto lens as he watches a ‘silent’ film of other people’s lives. To Hitchcock it was the visual construction of a mental process, ‘the epitome of the subjective treatment’. Cast includes James Stewart, Grace Kelly, Wendell Corey, Thelma Ritter. Screenplay by John Michael Hayes based on a the short story by Cornell Woolrich. Photography by Robert Burks. Music by Franz Waxman.

results.title: Reap the wild wind
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures and Cecil B. DeMille
results.brief_description: Shipwreck on the Reef, Shipwreck on the Reef, this was the cry the local shipowners and salvage operators in Key West during the 1840’s awaited. Their business thrived on the cargo of wrecked ships but are all the wrecks caused by nature or man made? Why is it that King Cutler (Raymond Massey) always seemed to be the first on the scene? These and other questions are asked by local ship owner Loxi Claiborne (Paulette Goddard) and others. Meanwhile Loxi’s suitor Captain Jack Stuart (John Wayne) is suspected by the jealous lawyer Steve Tolliver (Ray Milland). Who will win in the romance stakes? The star studded cast includes Robert Preston, Susan Heywood, Charles Bickford, Walter Hampden and Janet Beecher. This Cecil B. DeMille production of piracy, hot-blooded love and huge clipper ships gliding in the mist won an Academy Award for its Special Effects and was based on a Saturday Evening Post story by Thelma Strabel.
